questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with abdominal pain and diarrhoea for the past few hours, and noticed blood in the stool during the recent episodes. He also had two episodes of vomiting. On evaluation, he has a temperature of 39ºC with clinical signs of dehydration. All of the following are indications to initiate empirical antibiotic therapy in this patient, except?
questions.solution:
Two episodes of vomiting are not an indication for antibiotic therapy.

Stool analysis and culture is the initial investigation of choice and antibiotic therapy should be instituted based on microbiological evidence. However, empirical antibiotic therapy may be initiated if diarrhoea persists even with anti-diarrhoeal agents when the patient has grossly bloody stools, fever > 38.5°C, is immunocompromised or is an elderly patient. The empirical antibiotics of choice are either metronidazole or fluoroquinolones.

In a patient with acute diarrhoea, the following are indications for further evaluation:

  1. Profuse diarrhoea with dehydration
  2. Fever > 38.5°C (101°F)
  3. Bloody stools (dysentery)
  4. Duration > 48 hours without improvement
  5. History of recent antibiotic use
  6. Patients aged>50 years with associated acute abdominal pain 
  7. Patients aged>70 years
  8. Immunocompromised patients

questions.text: In which of the following types of diarrhoea would a patient's symptoms be likely to improve with fasting?
questions.solution:
Osmotic diarrhoea ceases with fasting.

Based on the mechanism by which it occurs, diarrhoea is classified broadly as secretory or osmotic.

Osmotic diarrhoea occurs when the contents in the gut contain osmotically active substances that draw fluid into the lumen resulting in loose stools. The presence of these contents may be due to ingestion of certain types of food, such as dairy products in the case of lactose intolerance, or abuse of drugs like osmotic laxatives. The patient's symptoms tend to subside once the inciting osmotic solute is removed. Osmotic diarrhoea is associated with a high stool osmotic gap.

Secretory diarrhoea (Option A) occurs due to an abnormality in fluid and electrolyte transport across the enteric mucosa. Clinically, it is differentiated from osmotic diarrhoea by the persistence of diarrhoea even after fasting and lack of stool osmotic gap. Secretory diarrhoea is typically watery, with large volume, and commonly occurs due to infective pathology, such as seen in cholera.

Although there may be some overlap in the mechanism, diarrhoea is also categorised as follows:

  • Inflammatory (Option B) - characterized by pain, fever and bleeding along with diarrhoea. eg - inflammatory bowel disease
  • Steatorrheal - loose stools which are foul-smelling, greasy and difficult to flush, occurring to various causes of fat malabsorption. eg -  pancreatitis, abetalipoproteinemia
  • Iatrogenic - following surgery such as vagotomy, bariatric surgery, or terminal ileal resection.
  • Factitious (Option D)  - in the case of eating disorders or psychiatric illness where the patient abuses laxatives or intentional contamination of stool with water
  • Motility disorders - such as autonomic neuropathy in diabetic adults

questions.text: A patient with Crohn's disease who has undergone terminal ileal resection complains of diarrhoea. On further questioning, you would be likely to learn that the stool has all of the following characteristics, except?
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea following terminal ileal resection would most likely be steatorrhoea. The typical description of steatorrhea is stool which is bulky, pale, greasy, foul-smelling and floats, hence making it difficult to flush.

Steatorrhoea refers to fatty stools and is quantitatively defined as stool fat > 7g/dl. It is caused due to fat malabsorption, as a result of which fatty acids in the gut lumen exert an osmotic effect and cause diarrhoea. Bile salts are essential for the absorption of fat from the gut. The ileum is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts. Following resection of the ileum, the loss of bile salts increases and is not met by an increase in synthesis and hence the depletion of the bile salt pool results in fat malabsorption and steatorrhea. The loss of bile salts into the colon affects the colonic mucosa, causing a reduction in salt and water absorption, which increases stool losses. 

Other causes of fat malabsorption and steatorrhea include exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, abetalipoproteinemia, celiac disease, alcohol consumption and biliary tract diseases such as gallstones and primary biliary cholangitis

questions.text: Which of the following organisms would not cause diarrhoea due to a pre-formed toxin?
questions.solution:
Enteropathogenic E. Coli (EPEC) does not cause a toxin-induced diarrhoea. 

EPEC causes diarrhoea mainly in infants and children by adhering to the mucosa leading to microvilli effacement. Adherence is regulated by EPEC adherence factor (EAF), a plasmid-encoded protein and locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE), which is regulated chromosomally. 

Other options:

Option A: Gastroenteritis caused by Staphylococcus aureus acts via preformed Type A enterotoxin. The common sources of infection are foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. 

Option B: Diarrhoea due to Bacillus cereus, typically associated with consumption of fried rice or Chinese street food is mediated by the preformed enterotoxin which causes ↑cAMP.

Option C: Food posioning by Clostridium perfringens is also enterotoxin mediated. The toxin also acts by causing fluid accumulation within the bowel due to ↑cAMP. Clostridial food poisoning is associated with consumption of reheated meat dishes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient admitted with a hemorrhagic stroke was trasnferred from the ICU to the ward 1 week ago. He has a tracheostomy and Ryle's tube in-situ, is on antiepileptics and antihypertensives, and is currently still in the hospital for physiotherapy. 3 days ago he was started on laxatives as he had not passed stools for 3 days before that. During evening rounds, the patient bystander complains that the patient has loose stools. Urine output is adequate. Which of the following would be the next best step ?

choices.text: Change the on-going Ryle's tube feeds

questions.solution:
The next best step in managing this patient would be to discontinue any laxatives as it is one of the possible causes for non-infectious diarrhoea.

Bed-ridden patients commonly develop altered bowel habits due to change in diet, lack of physical activity and use of medications. Diarrhoea due to laxative use is a common clinical scenario, especially in instances where patient bystanders are involved in medicating the patient as part of their rehabilitation and education prior to discharge.

This patient currently has no indications for starting IV fluids as adequate urine output suggests that there is no dehydration. Empirical antibiotics should only be started in case diarrhoea does not improve after 48 hours or there are other signs of infection. A change in Ryle's tube feed might be tried but would not be helpful in case laxatives are not discontinued.

questions.text: Apart from the presence of blood, which of the following features is more likely associated with dysentery as compared to diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
The term dysentery refers to bloody diarrhoea. However, there are other characteristics that differentiate the two, as follows:

Diarrhoea Dysentery
Voluminous fluid faeces Scanty sticky faeces
No blood in faeces Blood in faeces
No mucus in faeces Mucus in faeces
Less pus cells Abundant pus cells
Less straining during defecation Tenesmus

Other terms associated with blood in stool that are to be differentiated from dysentery are:

  • Malena - refers to the presence of altered blood in stool, which appears blackish, usually signifying an upper GI bleed.
  • Hematochezia - refers to the presence of frank red blood in stool, usually signifying fresh bleeding from the lower GI tract.

questions.text: In which of the following types of thyroid malignancies would a patient be most likely to complain of diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea is a common feature of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland. MTC secretes calcitonin, serotonin and prostaglandins which are secretory peptides that cause watery diarrhoea, which is not a common feature in other types of thyroid cancer. MTC is also associated with increased levels of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH). 

Important features of MTC include:

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion
  • Diarrhea due to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Blood-borne metastasis 
  • Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: A 60-year-old male was recently diagnosed with rectal carcinoma and is scheduled for elective surgery in the coming month. He visits the clinic complaining that over the past week, he has felt the urge to visit the toilet several times a day but only passes blood and mucus. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Spurious diarrhoea is a common and characteristic complaint in rectal carcinoma wherein the patient complains of diarrhoea as they evacuate the bowels multiple timea a day,  but pass only mucous and blood rather than faecal matter.

Symptoms of rectal carcinoma include:

  1. Painless bleeding - earliest and most common
  2. Alteration of bowel habits - change in frequency and consistency of the stool
  3. Tenesmus - unable to pass a motion even when there is the sensation of needing to evacuate the bowel. It is suggestive of a tumor of the lower half of the rectum 
  4. Early morning bloody diarrhea and spurious diarrhoea. Pain and weight loss are usually late symptoms

Abdominal examination and digital rectal examination are used for the primary evaluation. Rigid sigmoidoscopy is performed to obtain a biopsy. A synchronous tumor (primary tumor with a different origin than the one currently investigated) is excluded by performing a colonoscopy.

Patients with rectal carcinoma are staged according to the Modified Duke’s classification as follows:

A

Growth limited up to the rectal mucosa (option D)

B

B1: Tumor invading muscularis propria, no lymph node invasion.

B2: Tumors invading into or through serosa, no lymph node invasion.

C

C1: The tumour did not exceed the bowel wall, lymph node metastasis.

C2: Tumour exceeded the intestinal wall and lymph node metastasis.

D

Distant metastasis

Surgery is the mainstay of management for rectal carcinoma. Non-operative management is offered to only those patients who have a complete clinical response to neoadjuvant.

The type of surgery depends on multiple factors (size, location, age of the patient, etc). However, the general consensus is:

  1. Early cancer (T1 and a few T2) is locally excised via the transanal approach.
  2. Most rectal cancer is treated by anterior resection and colorectal/coloanal anastomosis.
  3. Low extensive tumors are treated by laparoscopic abdominoperineal resection(APR) and permanent colostomy.
  4. Hartmann’s operation is preferred in old and frail patients due to poor anal sphincter and postoperative incontinence.

Other options:

Option A: Factitious diarrhoea refers to a form of malingering or psychiatric illness (Munchausen's syndrome) wherein the patient complains of diarrhoea in the absence of an organic cause as they add water or urine to the stool to create the impression of loose stools.

Option B: Hematochezia refers to the presence of frank, bright-red blood in stool and may be a presenting feature of rectal carcinoma.

Option C: Dysentery refers to the presence of blood and mucous along with faecal matter.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer

The risk factors for colorectal cancer are:

  • Dietary:
    • High-animal-fat diet
    • Low-fiber diet
    • Alcohol
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • FAP
    • HNPCC
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Cholecystectomy: increased right colon cancer due to exposure to bile acids
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy
  • Smoking
  • Acromegaly
  • Pelvic irradiation

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with complaints of headache, vomiting and diarrhoea associated with lower abdominal pain since her period started two days ago. She has previously had regular menstrual cycles with no excessive bleeding , but has had similar symptoms in almost every preceding month since she first started having periods. Abdominal, vaginal and systemic examination findings are all normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of lower abdominal pain associated with symptoms such as headache, vomiting and diarrhoea, during the beginning of menstrual cycles is suggestive of primary dysmenorrhea. Onset within 2 years of menarche further supports the diagnosis.

Dysmenorrhea is defined as cramping pain accompanying menstruation. It is further classified as follows:

A. Etiological classification:

  • Primary dysmenorrhea does not have an associated organic cause but is associated with increased circulating prostaglandins which are responsible for the systemic and non-specific symptoms such as headache, vomiting and diarrhoea.
  • Secondary (acquired) dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of organic pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, PID, and endometriosis.

B.  Clinical classification:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the most prevalent type characterized by cramping pain before or at the start of menstruation, especially on the first and second days of menstruation.
  • Congestive dysmenorrhea is seen in PID, IUCD users, pelvic vein varicosities, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids. These patients have increasing pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain a few days before menstruation after which they have rapid relief of the symptoms. 
  • Membranous dysmenorrhea is characterized by endometrial shedding as a cast during menses, and this passage of cast leads to painful uterine cramps. It is the rarest variety.

Primary dysmenorrhea is managed supportively with symptomatic treatment using NSAIDs, antispasmodics and antiemetics. 

Other options:

Options A and B : Patients with gastroenteritis may have symptoms such as vomiting and diarrhoea, associated with headache, and patients with influenza might also be likely to have fever and malaise but these may occur without any temporal association with the onset of menstral cycles.

Option C: Catamenial migraine refers to migraine headaches occurring in women before, or at the onset of menstrual cycles. Symptoms are likely to be more typical of migraine with the presence of an aura, with longer lasting headaches and severe nausea.

questions.text:
Assertion: Loperamide should not be administered to children with acute diarrhea
Reason: Loperamide is a synthetic opiate that causes reduction of gut motility

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.solution:
Loperamide should not be administered to children with acute diarrhea because it is a synthetic opiate that causes a reduction of gut motility. Inhibition of gut motility/ intestinal peristalsis results in more time for harmful bacterial multiplication within the gut. Also, synthetic opiates may result in distension of abdomen, paralytic ileus, bacterial overgrowth and sepsis when used in children with acute diarrhea and may even prove fatal in infants. 

So,

Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted to the hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed diarrhea and abdominal pain. Her temperature was 38.8 degrees Celcius. Her blood reports are given below. What is the most probable etiological agent?
  • Hemoglobin- 12 g/dL
  • WBC count of 18,000/mm3
  • CRP of 160 mg/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with hospital-acquired diarrhea (nosocomial) following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridium difficile. 

Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of infectious diarrhea in nosocomial infection. 

It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • Lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • Fever, leukocytosis
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis

Investigations:

  • Nucleic acid amplification tests, including polymerase chain reaction assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool 
  • Stool culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating toxin by cell cytotoxin cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy reveals a characteristic pseudomembrane.

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool, have now been approved for diagnostic purposes and appear to be both rapid and sensitive while retaining high specificity.

Oral vancomycin, metronidazole, and fidaxomicin are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

First choice treatment of C. difficile colitis:

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral vancomycin OR fidaxomicin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline) Oral vancomycin OR fidaxomicin
Severe, complicated (shock, ileus, toxic megacolon) Oral vancomycin + IV metronidazole ± Rectal vancomycin
Recurrent/ multiple episodes Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT)

Recent update: Harrison's 20th edition recommends the use of vancomycin over metronidazole in the treatment of initial episodes which are mild to moderate in severity. Metronidazole is recommended only if vancomycin or fidaxomicin is not accessible. Oral metronidazole is less effective than the other options and may necessitate a longer treatment course for a response.

Other options: Escherichia coli, Norovirus, Rotavirus are all causes of Traveller's diarrhea.

Other causes of Nosocomial diarrhea:

  • Clostridium perfringens,
  • Klebsiella oxytoca,
  • Staphylococcus aureus.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A family of four from London developed recurrent episodes of watery diarrhea and abdominal pain after their trip to Bali. Stool culture on MacConkey medium is given below. Biochemical tests done show IMViC ++-- and negative Eiken's test. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin secreted by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette along with lactose fermenting MacConkey agar (bright pink), IMViC : ++--, and negative Eiken's test is suggestive of Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)/traveler's diarrhea caused by the E. coli heat-stable enterotoxin which acts by activation of cGMP in the intestine.

Persons from developed countries visiting endemic areas often suffer from ETEC diarrhea, a condition known as Traveler's diarrhea. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is the most common cause of Traveler’s Diarrhoea. It can range from mild watery diarrhea to fatal disease, similar to cholera.

The first step in pathogenesis is adherence to the intestinal mucosa by fimbria called colonization factor antigens. ETEC then produces enterotoxins which may be either heat-labile (LT) or heat-stable (ST).

This is distinguished by several tests, one of the serological tests being Precipitin test (Eikien's) which is positive in LT and negative in ST. IMViC test includes indole, methyl red (MR), Voges-Proskauer (VP) and citrate utilisation. E.coli is indole positive and MR positive, and VP negative and citrate negative.

Two types of heat-stable enterotoxins are known :

  1. STa/ST I
  2. STb/ST II

STa acts by activation of the cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) in the intestine. This is rapid and accumulates fluid in the intestine in the infant mice (infant mouse test) which is the standard method for the demonstration of STa.

The mode of action of STb is unknown but it is neither through cAMP or cGMP.

ETEC with heat-labile enterotoxins act by activation of cAMP.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with diarrhoea and abdominal pain for the past 7 days after eating biriyani at an Arabian restaurant. His diarrhea can be best classified as?
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea lasting for less than 2 weeks is defined as acute diarrhoea. (According to Harrison's 21st edition, CMDT mentions </= 7 days)

Diarrhoea can be broadly characterized as the excretion of unusually liquid or unformed faeces with an elevated frequency. In the context of individuals adhering to a standard Western diet, a stool weight above 200 g per day can generally indicate diarrhoea. Typically, healthcare professionals define diarrhoea as a condition characterized by an elevated number of bowel movements (exceeding three per day) or the presence of loose or watery stool consistency. Diarrhoea can be classified into three categories based on its duration: acute, persistent, and chronic. Acute diarrhoea refers to cases lasting less than two weeks, while persistent diarrhoea lasts between two and four weeks. Chronic diarrhoea is characterised by a duration beyond four weeks.

Two prevalent illnesses are often characterized by the excretion of less than 200 grams of stool per day. 

Pseudodiarrhoea, characterised by the frequent excretion of small amounts of faeces, is commonly observed in conjunction with symptoms such as rectal urgency, tenesmus, and a sensation of incomplete bowel movement. This condition is commonly observed in individuals with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or proctitis. Faecal incontinence refers to the involuntary expulsion of rectal contents and is primarily attributed to neuromuscular disorders or structural anorectal abnormalities. 

Causes of acute diarrhoea can be classified under :

  Non-inflammatory diarrhoea Inflammatory diarrhoea
Appearance Watery, without blood, pus, or mucus  Loose to watery, often with blood, pus, or mucus 
Viral Noroviruses, astrovirus, adenovirus, rotavirus, SARS-CoV-2  Cytomegalovirus 
Parasite Giardia lamblia Cryptosporidium Cyclospora  Entamoeba histolytica
Bacteria

1. Preformed enterotoxin production 

  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Bacillus cereus
  • Clostridium perfringens 

2. Enterotoxin production Enterotoxigenic 

  • Escherichia coli (ETEC)
  • Vibrio cholera,
  • Vibrio vulnificus 

1. Cytotoxin production Enterohemorrhagic E coli 

  • O157:H5 and O157:H7 (EHEC) 
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus 
  • Clostridioides difficile 

2. Mucosal invasion 

  • Shigella
  • Campylobacter jejuni
  • Salmonella
  • Enteroinvasive E coli (EIEC)
  • Listeria monocytogenes
  • Aeromonas
  • Yersinia enterocolitica 

3. Infectious proctitis 

  • Chlamydia
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with diarrhea and abdominal pain. He can be advised to eat any of the following except?
questions.solution:
Among the given options cottage cheese is not advisable to be consumed in patients with acute diarrhoea. All dairy products must be restricted in patients with acute diarrhoea.

In the majority of cases, mild to moderate diarrhoea does not typically result in dehydration as long as the patient consumes sufficient oral fluids that contain carbohydrates and electrolytes. Patients often have greater comfort when they choose to abstain from consuming foods that are high in fibre, fats, milk products, caffeine, and alcohol since these dietary choices can help alleviate bowel-related discomfort. The use of tea, carbonated beverages with low levels of carbonation, and readily digestible foods such as soups, crackers, bananas, applesauce, rice, and bread is recommended. Some sources describe this diet as a BRAT diet which consists of bananas, rice, applesauce, and toast. 

The glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption is the principle behind replacing glucose and sodium in a 1:1 molar ratio in the WHO oral rehydration solution (ORS). The low osmolarity of the ORS in the lumen as compared to the blood facilitates the absorption of fluid and hence the electrolytes due to the solvent drag. Studies have shown that low osmolarity ORS causes a reduction of stool output, a decrease in vomiting and a decrease in the use of unscheduled intravenous fluids without increasing the risk of hyponatremia. Other home available fluids that can be used are salted rice water/salted yoghurt drinks, and vegetable/chicken soup with salt.

In the context of individuals adhering to a standard Western diet, a stool weight above 200 g per day can generally indicate diarrhoea. Two prevalent illnesses are often characterized by the excretion of less than 200 grams of stool per day.

This condition is commonly observed in individuals with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or proctitis. questions.text: A 7-year-old girl with complaints of bloody diarrhoea for the past 6 days is found to be infected with E. coli O157:H7. Which of the following is contraindicated in the management of this child?
questions.solution:
Antibiotics are contraindicated in the management of enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) infection, especially in children. This is because antibiotics induce the replication of Shiga toxin–producing bacteriophages and increase toxin production which may worsen the disease and significantly increase the risk of developing hemolytic-uremic syndrome and renal failure.

O157: H7 is a strain of E.coli called enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) which produces verocytotoxin or Shiga-like-toxin. Shiga toxin acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It is absorbed from the inflamed gastrointestinal mucosa into the circulation and causes endothelial dysfunction, and causes platelet activation and aggregation. Children and older adults are at the highest risk. It causes mild non-bloody diarrhea to hemorrhagic colitis, or a severe form of dysentery, with hemolytic uremic syndrome, a disease resulting in acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

EHEC are gram-negative bacilli which are lactose fermenting. Unlike most other E. coli serotypes, O157: H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar, whereas other serotypes produces pink colonies. 

EHEC dysentery is commonly self-limiting and management is conservative with the mainstay being correction of dehydration and electrolyte imbalances and other symptomatic supportive treatment such as blood tranfusion in case of severe blood loss anaemia, but antibiotics are not to be used.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man with diarrhoea and abdominal pain for the past 7 days after eating biriyani at an Arabian restaurant. He has had two episodes of vomiting and 4 episodes of diarrhoea over the last 1 day. On evaluation, he has a temperature of 37.5ºC and a capillary refill time of 1 second. Which of the following features present in him warrants further investigation of his acute diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
This patient's acute diarrhoea would require further testing as he is aged more than 70 years.

Concomitant features in patients with acute diarrhoea that warrant further testing include:

Severe illness

  • Fever >/= 38.5 degree Celsius (101.3 degrees Fahrenheit) 
  • Signs or symptoms of hypovolemia
  • >/= 6 unformed stools per 24 hours
  • Severe abdominal pain

High-risk host features 

  • Age >/= 70 years
  • Comorbidities such as cardiac disease, immunocompromising conditions (including advanced HIV ie CD4<200 cells)

Diarrhoea lasting for less than 2 weeks is defined as acute diarrhoea. (According to Harrison's 21st edition, CMDT mentions </= 7 days)

Diarrhoea can be broadly characterized as the excretion of unusually liquid or unformed faeces with an elevated frequency. In the context of individuals adhering to a standard Western diet, a stool weight above 200 g per day can generally indicate diarrhoea. Typically, healthcare professionals define diarrhoea as a condition characterized by an elevated number of bowel movements (exceeding three per day) or the presence of loose or watery stool consistency. Diarrhoea can be classified into three categories based on its duration: acute, persistent, and chronic. Acute diarrhoea refers to cases lasting less than two weeks, while persistent diarrhoea lasts between two and four weeks. Chronic diarrhoea is characterised by a duration beyond four weeks.

Two prevalent illnesses are often characterized by the excretion of less than 200 grams of stool per day. 

Pseudodiarrhoea, characterised by the frequent excretion of small amounts of faeces, is commonly observed in conjunction with symptoms such as rectal urgency, tenesmus, and a sensation of incomplete bowel movement. This condition is commonly observed in individuals with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or proctitis. Faecal incontinence refers to the involuntary expulsion of rectal contents and is primarily attributed to neuromuscular disorders or structural anorectal abnormalities.

  • Bacillus cereus

  • Vibrio cholera,
  • Vibrio vulnificus

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with diarrhoea and abdominal pain for the past 15 days after eating biriyani at an Arabian restaurant. Which of the following tests best helps distinguish between an inflammatory or a non-inflammatory etiology of this patient's diarrhea?
questions.solution:
The faecal lactoferrin agglutination assay test is the best test to distinguish between inflammatory and non-inflammatory causes of acute diarrhoea owing to a very high sensitivity and specificity of 90%.

Diarrhoea lasting for less than 2 weeks is defined as acute diarrhoea. (According to Harrison's 21st edition, CMDT mentions </= 7 days)

Diarrhoea can be broadly characterized as the excretion of unusually liquid or unformed faeces with an increased frequency. Acute diarrhoea refers to cases lasting less than two weeks, while persistent diarrhoea lasts between two and four weeks. Chronic diarrhoea is characterised by a duration beyond four weeks.

Other options:

Option B: With a sensitivity and specificity of 70% and 50% respectively, faecal leukocytes are a poor indicator of an inflammatory aetiology of diarrhoea.

Option C: The incidence of positive stool cultures in cases of acute diarrhoea is generally quite low, except in individuals with very severe disease. 

Option D: The stool guaiac test is also not as sensitive or specific as that of fecal lactoferrin to detect a difference between inflammatory and non-inflammatory diarrhoea.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents with sudden onset loose stools, vomiting, and muscular cramps. Stools were colorless, like rice water, and had an inoffensive sweetish odor. Identify the false statement regarding the causative agent.

TCBS - Thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose

choices.text: Can cause metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia
Produces greyish black colonies on TCBS medium

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of sudden onset colorless rice watery, stools having an inoffensive sweetish odor is indicative of cholera and the causative agent is Vibrio cholerae. They produce large yellow convex colonies on the TCBS medium.

The cells of Vibrio cholerae are gram-negative and typically comma-shaped. They show darting motility, with a single sheathed polar flagellum. They are aerobic and produce large yellow convex colonies on the thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose (TCBS) medium.

They are late lactose fermenters, producing pink colonies on MacConkey agar after prolonged incubation. They are aerobic. Special media for transporting and cultivating vibrio species are:

  • Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium
  • Cary-Blair medium
  • Autoclaved seawater
  • Enrichment media like Monsur's taurocholate tellurite peptone water 
  • Plating media:
    • Alkaline bile salt agar
    • Monsur's gelatin taurocholate trypticase tellurite agar (GTTA)
    • Thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose agar (colonies shown in the image below)

Vibrio colonies may be identified by the 'string test', where a loopful of the growth is mixed with a drop of 0.5% sodium deoxycholate in saline on a slide. The suspension loses its turbidity, becomes mucoid, and forms a 'string' when the loop is drawn away slowly in a positive test.

The cholera toxin disrupts the zona occludens. It activates cellular adenylate cyclase leading to the accumulation of cAMP. It consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The active A subunit enters the enterocyte and dissociates into A1 and A2. A2 fragment only links the biologically active A1 to the B subunit.

A1 causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. This leads to watery diarrhea which is isotonic with plasma but contains much more potassium and bicarbonate. This results in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis. The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride.

Oral administration of fluid containing glucose and electrolytes is a highly effective, economical method of treating cholera.

questions.text: A young man presents with sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of passing loose stools. He gives a history of having food from a nearby bakery three hours ago. Which of the following organisms is most likely implicated here?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of acute food poisoning most likely caused by Staphylococcus aureus. 

Food poisoning by Staphylococcus aureus is caused due to ingestion of preformed enterotoxin. The preformed enterotoxin is heat-stable. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known, of which, Type A toxin is responsible for most cases. It contaminates food products such as meat, fish, milk products, mayonnaise, cream pastries, etc. when left at room temperature for a long time.

Enterotoxin acts directly on the autonomic nervous system to cause food poisoning, rather than on the gastrointestinal mucosa. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity.

Staphylococcal food poisoning has a very short incubation period of about 1 - 8 hours. Patients usually present with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food.

Other options:

Option A: Vibrio cholera leads to dysentery that presents with acute, profuse, watery stools (rice water stools) and vomiting which may lead to severe dehydration, hypokalemia, and shock. The incubation period is usually around 1-5 days. 

Option B: Salmonella typhi can present with diarrheal disease along with typical step-ladder patterns of fever, relative bradycardia, malaise, and abdominal discomfort. The incubation period is usually around 7-14 days.

Option C: Infection with Bacillus cereus causes food poisoning with a longer incubation period of 8-16 hours. But patients usually have a history of consumption of fried rice.
